title: 110_hr634
content: The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the sacrifices of disabled veterans and aims to mint a commemorative silver dollar coin in their honor. Congress acknowledges the service and sacrifices of veterans from various wars and emphasizes the importance of honoring those who have served and those who have made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act authorizes the minting of a commemorative silver dollar coin to honor living disabled veterans. The coin specifications include a weight of 26.73 grams, a diameter of 1.500 inches, and a composition of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under the American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act should symbolize the service of disabled veterans. The coins will have inscriptions including the coin's value, the year "2010", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant organizations, will select the design for the coins minted under the American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint used to strike each quality. It is recommended that the coins be struck at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The coins may only be issued during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010, and will be sold at a price equal to the face value plus a surcharge. The coins issued under the American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge of $10 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. Surcharges received from coin sales will be paid to Disabled Veterans. The surcharge for each coin sold under the American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act is $10. Surcharges received will be paid to the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation to support the construction of the American Veterans' Disabled for Life Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Foundation's expenditures. There is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs that can be issued in a calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for commemorative coin programs exceeding the annual issuance limitation.
